DOCNAME: CASE OF VERAART v. THE NETHERLANDS
CONCLUSION: Violation of Art. 10;Costs and expenses partial award - Convention proceedings
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant is a GPE national who was born in DATE ; he is an advocate practising in GPE ( GPE ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG , a private organisation holding a public broadcasting license , broadcast a television documentary entitled “ Secret mothers ” ( PERSON moeders ) . It featured a woman , CARDINAL PERSON , who claimed to have been the victim of incest committed by her grandfather , her father and CARDINAL of her brothers .

CARDINAL . PERSON alleged that CARDINAL pregnancies had resulted . CARDINAL had been terminated . Of the babies born from the other CARDINAL , CARDINAL had been ritually murdered and one had been sold .

CARDINAL . These statements were said to be based on memories which PERSON had repressed but which she had been able to recover with the aid of a therapist , PERSON , who had been treating her for DATE .
CARDINAL . The PERSON family , who denied the truth of PERSON allegations , sought the assistance of the applicant .
CARDINAL . The GPE public prosecutor ( officier van justitie ) opened a prosecution file , charging the ORG with criminal libel .

CARDINAL . On DATE the public prosecution service published a press release in which it was stated that the ORG had admitted having libelled the PERSON family and had settled out of court . The prosecution had been dropped subject to the conditions , which the ORG had accepted , that the ORG would pay a sum of money to the public prosecution service , publish a retraction and pay the PERSON family compensation for pecuniary and nonpecuniary damage and legal costs .

CARDINAL . On DATE another private organisation holding a public broadcasting license , the ORG , broadcast a radio programme featuring an interview with the applicant about the case of the PERSON family .
CARDINAL . The applicant said , among other things :

“ Here we are faced with a dangerous group of individuals who ... [ though ] unproved , nonetheless present , er , a horrible crime . I mean , we 're talking about CARDINAL infanticides , we 're not talking about nothing . ... all right , QUANTITY murders , CARDINAL abortion and CARDINAL child allegedly sold , whatever , it 's a terrible accusation and you ca n't just do that . That should not go unpunished . ”
The interviewer explained that the reference was to
“ ... alternative therapies such as hypnosis and regression therapy ... ”
going on to say :

“ The alternative therapist who was treating PERSON at the time was PERSON . He actually does believe in recovered memories , and therefore also in the recollection of incest and of quadruple infanticide . ”
CARDINAL . Referring to the intuitive methods used by PERSON , the interviewer stated :
“ So , PERSON can sense and see whether people have been sexually abused . ”
The applicant responded , saying , among other things :

“ I ca n't understand how he , how he can do that ! To me , that shows how dangerous these therapists are . Someone like that should n't , should not be allowed to be a therapist surely ? That man , he lives in GPE province , he should , er , grow cabbages for the market ... He should go and grow cabbages out there , but he should absolutely not be working with with with patients , or with people who who are in emergency situations . I find this very worrying . I consider this very unprofessional . It 's possible of course [ that ] these people are NORP ( magiërs ) , that has nothing to do with therapists , nothing to do with doctors . They take people back in regression therapy . Where was that man educated ? Where did that man study ? I have no idea , and what does he presume to be ? That man likens himself to God . There is no medical practitioner , surely , who could say that ? ”
CARDINAL . Later in the programme , referring to a conversation which PERSON had had with PERSON parents in DATE , the applicant said , among other things :

“ ... I just ca n't imagine how anyone can be so presumptuous as to tell CARDINAL vulnerable old people , like some sort of guru , and , er , his truth , and then give them an audio tape and tell them : well , go and listen carefully to what I have said . Such arrogance . In my opinion it 's quite terrible . Well , if you know that father PERSON died shortly after that , he went to his grave accused by him , right , accused by a relative ... ”

CARDINAL . NORP The programme also comprised an interview with PERSON , who stated that he was neither a hypnotist nor a regression therapist properly socalled . He believed , however , that the emotions aroused by relaxation exercises and acupressure reflected true events and he was certain that the memories which he had helped PERSON recover were the truth .
CARDINAL . On DATE Mr PERSON lodged a complaint against the applicant with the PERSON ( deken ) of ORG ( PERSON ) .
CARDINAL . The PERSON gave a provisional opinion on DATE . It mentions that PERSON was asked , on DATE , to state his medical and scientific qualifications but declined to do so .

CARDINAL . The PERSON noted that Mr PERSON 's refusal to state his qualifications did not , at any rate , indicate that the applicant 's statements were incorrect . However , it was understandable that Mr PERSON should feel aggrieved and it was not clear that the interests of the PERSON family were served by the applicant 's statements .
CARDINAL . The provisional conclusion was that the complaint was well - founded . The PERSON forwarded Mr PERSON 's complaint to ORG ( ORG ) on DATE .

CARDINAL . ORG held a hearing on DATE . On DATE it gave a decision finding Mr PERSON 's complaint unfounded . It recognised that the PERSON family had a legitimate interest in contesting , in the media and elsewhere , the accusations levelled against them by PERSON ; the applicant 's expressions , though forceful , had not been disproportionate .
CARDINAL . Mr PERSON appealed to ORG ) .

CARDINAL . That ORG held a hearing on DATE , at which it was stated among other things that PERSON had been practising as a self - employed psychotherapist since DATE . He had been trained at ORG , after which he had taken some practical and theoretical courses and a DATE course on multi - method relationship therapy . He was a recognised member , supervisor and trainer of ORG ( PERSON ) . He was associated with the private foundation ( ORG ( PERSON Registratie- , Certificatie- en Ontwikkelingsinstituut PERSON , also known as “ Registration Institute for Nature - Oriented Health Care ” , GPE - instituut PERSON , or “ RING ” ) , which had set up a disciplinary system .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG gave its decision . It considered that a lawyer had not to judge the quality of a particular therapeutic method . Although PERSON had levelled accusations against her family involving CARDINAL pregnancies , CARDINAL infanticides , an abortion and the sale of a baby , PERSON PERSON had not been present when she did so ; the applicant should therefore not have connected Mr PERSON to them .

CARDINAL . Nor should he have suggested that PERSON alleged repressed memories had been caused by PERSON use of hypnotism or regression therapy , PERSON not having claimed to be a hypnotist or a regression therapist . The applicant had been unclear in explaining what improper therapeutic measures exactly he held against PERSON .

CARDINAL . The conversation between Mr PERSON and PERSON parents in DATE , also criticised by the applicant , had not been part of the therapy . In any case , the applicant 's criticism of that conversation was unfounded given that the applicant had not clearly explained why he considered Mr PERSON negligent in his therapeutic methods .

CARDINAL . The applicant 's vagueness might have been defensible if only he had chosen to make the interview a “ clarion call ” ( klaroenstoot ) preparatory to a civil suit to follow shortly after , but no civil suit had ever been brought .

CARDINAL . The applicant had not been entitled either to describe Mr PERSON as a “ magus ” who “ likened himself to God ” . Mr PERSON had in fact stated , in his DATE conversation with PERSON parents , his reasons for believing the truth of PERSON statements , and he had been careful to spare them feelings of guilt for the acts of their sons and to avoid labelling the sons as delinquents .

CARDINAL . Whether or not the applicant could be said to have used “ irony ” , as he argued , the way in which he had expressed himself had been unnecessarily wounding ( onnodig grievend ) for PERSON .
CARDINAL . Mr PERSON 's complaint was therefore well - founded . Since the applicant had a clean record , he was given a mere admonition ( CARDINAL waarschuwing ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE Mr PERSON , through his counsel , informed the ORG that he had instituted civil proceedings in the competent domestic tribunal , which proceedings had been adjourned pending the ORG 's decision .

CARDINAL . The PERSON family brought an action for damages against Mr PERSON on DATE , based on what the applicant describes as the escalation of PERSON problems and the statements made by PERSON as to the veracity of Ms A.K.s alleged recollections .
CARDINAL . DATE the Kingdom of the GPE provides as follows :

“ CARDINAL . No one shall require prior permission to make public thoughts or feelings ( gedachten of gevoelens ) in printed form , the individual responsibility of everyone under the law notwithstanding .
CARDINAL . There shall be statutory rules governing radio and television . There shall be no prior control of the content of a radio or television broadcast .

CARDINAL . No one shall require prior permission to make public thoughts or feelings in any other way than those mentioned in the preceding paragraphs , the individual responsibility of everyone under the law notwithstanding . ...
CARDINAL . The preceding paragraphs are not applicable to commercial advertising . ”
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of LAW ( GPE ) provides as follows :

“ Advocates shall be subject to disciplinary proceedings regarding any act or omission which is in breach of the due care they ought to exercise as advocates visàvis those whose interests they look after , or ought to look after , any breach of the Regulations of the National Bar , and any act or omission not befitting a respectable advocate ( enig handelen of nalaten dat een behoorlijk advocaat niet betaamt ) . This disciplinary justice shall be dispensed at first instance by ORG , and , on appeal , by ORG , which shall also be the highest instance . ”

CARDINAL . Guidance on the nature of an “ act or omission not befitting a respectable advocate ” is found in LAW advocaten ) , the most recent version of which dates from DATE . The Rules relevant to the present case are the following :
“ Advocates should conduct themselves in such a way that confidence in the profession or in their own exercise of the profession is not diminished . ”
“ Advocates should not express themselves , either orally or in writing , in a way that is unnecessarily wounding . ”
